content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" is cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports to Budget Committees, and completion of action on the budget resolution by Congress. The congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports to Budget Committees, and completion of action on the budget resolution by Congress. Biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill may be considered in the House as provided in subsection (b) by May 15. The House Appropriations Committee reports the last appropriation bill to be considered that year by June 10. Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation by June 15. By June 30, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills by August 1. On June 30, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. Congress completes action on these bills by August 1. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, with a new President, specific dates will override the usual schedule. The schedule for budget-related actions includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports to Budget Committees, resolution on the budget by Budget Committees, and completion of action by Congress. Biennial appropriation bills and defense appropriation bills have specific dates for consideration in the House. On July 20, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. By August 1, Congress completes action on the biennial appropriation bills, defense appropriation bill, and reconciliation legislation. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for various sectors. In even-numbered years, Congress follows the budget process to consider appropriation bills. In even-numbered years, Congress considers and enacts appropriation bills for Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Military Construction, Veterans Affairs, Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define a biennium as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations for appropriations are adjusted to cover all fiscal years in the resolution, including defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to adjust committee allocations for appropriations to cover all fiscal years in the resolution, including defense and each fiscal year in the biennium. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years, including changes to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, and allowances for each fiscal year in the biennium and the succeeding 4 years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years, including changes to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, and tax expenditures for each fiscal year in the biennium. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years, including changes to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, and tax expenditures for each fiscal year in the biennium. Additionally, amendments are made to sections 1105(a)(14), 1105(a)(16), and 1105(a)(17) by specifying the fiscal years and bienniums for budget submissions. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years, including changes to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, and tax expenditures. Sections 1105(a)(18) and 1105(a)(19) are amended to specify the most recently completed fiscal years for outlays and receipts. Sections 1105(a)(18) and 1105(a)(19) are amended to specify the most recently completed fiscal years for outlays and receipts, with adjustments made to references of time periods. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years, including changes to receipts, balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, and tax expenditures. Sections 1105(b) and 1105(c) are amended to specify adjustments to estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches, as well as recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies in each fiscal year of the biennium. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Sections 1105(b) and 1105(c) are amended to specify adjustments to estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches, as well as recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies in each fiscal year of the biennium. Additionally, Section 1105(e)(1) is amended to change references from "ensuing fiscal year" to "biennium to which such budget relates". SEC. 5. Two-year appropriations; title and style of appropriations acts. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will have a specific format for each fiscal year in a biennium, while defense Acts will be titled for a specific fiscal year. All Acts making regular appropriations must include specified amounts. The style and title of Acts for defense appropriations shall be specified as 'An Act making appropriations for defense for fiscal year (insert fiscal year)'. Acts making regular appropriations must specify the amounts provided for each fiscal year. Definitions for terms like 'biennium' are provided in this section. Section 3(12) of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 and Acts described in subsection (a)(1) are considered as provided in section 300(b) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. A technical and conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 2 of title 1, United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless the program will require no further appropriations. It also restricts authorization or revenue bills until Congress completes action on the budget resolution and all appropriations bills. In the Senate, this does not apply to defense or privileged measures. The joint resolution prohibits considering appropriations bills until Congress completes action on the budget resolution and reconciliation bills. Certain exceptions apply in the Senate, including defense measures and privileged considerations. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT requires joint oversight hearings on agency activities not funded under certain conditions. The hearing reviews agency mission, impact of biennial budgeting, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD is also included. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will study the impact of changing the fiscal year to a 2-year period with a biennial budget process. A report on the findings will be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting in fiscal year 2017.
